importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 21, 2025, indicating the current status and development of the Reefline project as of that date.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Reefline project is expected to take at least a decade to complete, with construction beginning in 2025 and full development anticipated by around 2035.

keyTakeAways: Reefline is a 7-mile-long artificial reef being developed near Miami Beach, combining marine art and coral restoration to revive a once-extant but lost reef.
The project includes underwater sculptures, such as 22 concrete cars arranged in a traffic jam, designed to act as coral substrates and habitats.
Coral species like gorgonians are being grown in nurseries and transplanted onto the reef to restore coral ecosystems and support marine life.
The project is co-led by Colin Foord, a coral researcher and founder of Coral Morphologic, and Ximena Caminos, an arts curator and cultural placemaker.
The project is funded partially by a $5 million Miami Beach city bond and aims to raise $6 million more for its first phase.
The Reefline project is designed to be accessible to the public through shallow water (15–20 feet), allowing divers to experience it without boats.
Artists like Leandro Ehrlich are involved, with his car sculptures expected to be overtaken by coral growth over time.
The project is rooted in both ecological restoration and artistic innovation, aiming to become a symbol of Miami Beach and promote ecotourism and environmental awareness.
It is intended to restore a lost natural feature of Miami Beach, which once had an offshore coral reef that was smothered by sand in the 1970s.
An onshore marine learning center will be established to educate the public about coral reef conservation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Reefline project in Miami Beach is a 7-mile-long artificial reef combining marine art and coral restoration, aiming to revive a lost offshore reef that once existed in the 1970s. Led by coral researcher Colin Foord and arts curator Ximena Caminos, the project features underwater sculptures—such as concrete cars and starfish—designed to serve as coral substrates. Corals like gorgonians are grown in nurseries and transplanted onto the structures, where they will grow over time, transforming the art into a living reef. Funded in part by a $5 million Miami Beach bond and seeking an additional $6 million, the project is expected to take at least a decade to complete and will include an onshore learning center to promote coral reef conservation. Artistic elements, including those by Leandro Ehrlich, are designed to become hidden beneath coral growth, symbolizing the integration of art and nature. The project not only restores ecological balance but also creates a unique, accessible ecotourism destination visible from the air and accessible to divers in shallow water.
title: Miami Beach puts the art in offshore artificial reef
